_meta.description: Cross-reference of EP01 on-screen navigation parameters with computed orbital mechanics

comparison.verdict: EXCELLENT MATCH — on-screen display is physically accurate within rounding

computed.method: vis-viva at 1.5 RJ with V∞=12.0, then subtract 2.3 km/s

perijoveBurn.keyFinding: The -2.3 km/s burn at 1.5 RJ drops velocity below escape speed (48.61 km/s), capturing the ship into a bound Jupiter orbit. This is the minimum ΔV for capture via Oberth effect at this perijove — the show's navigation computer is computing real orbital mechanics.

ganymedeApproach.keyFinding: After capture, the ship passes through Ganymede's orbit at 12.48 km/s vs Ganymede's 10.88 km/s — a relative velocity of only 1.60 km/s, manageable for a final approach burn.

entryBurn.interpretation: The +2.4 km/s Phase 2 burn occurs during Jupiter approach. This shapes the approach trajectory to achieve the desired perijove altitude (1.5 RJ) and azimuth (282.14°). The 11h 42m countdown matches the remaining transit time to perijove at approach velocities.

computed.note: V∞=12.0 is 2.8× the Hohmann V∞ (4.27 km/s), consistent with a high-energy brachistochrone transfer from Mars

analysis.linearity: Nearly linear above 65%. 65%→100% scales by 1.56 (expected: 1.54), 100%→110% scales by 1.09 (expected: 1.10). Thrust-output relationship is highly linear.
analysis.peak_specific_note: 110% is the over-rated emergency mode visible when cockpit enters red alert

marsDeparture.keyFinding: At 52° apparent diameter, Kestrel is approximately 560 km above Mars surface (2.05 Mars radii from center). This is consistent with being just past the 50,000 km RCS-only zone and beginning main engine burns.
